0.00.text:
Translator: Robert Tucker
Reviewer: Krystian Aparta

14.11.text:
So, many of you may not recognize
this person on the screen.

20.59.text: He lives here in Portland, Oregon.

23.06.text:
He was named the 17th most influential
person of the century by Time magazine.

31.84.text:
This is Linus Torvalds,
and if you've never heard of him,

36.92.text:
you've probably heard
of the software he created.

40.29.text:
Linus Torvalds created Linux,
the world's most successful software.

49.00.text: It runs everything. I'm not kidding.

53.13.text: It's in your phone, it's in a car,

57.01.text:
it's in your television,
it runs your bank,

60.26.text:
it runs most of the global economy,
it runs air-traffic control systems,

65.30.text:
nuclear submarines,
it runs most of the Internet.

69.64.text: You use Linux every single day,

73.19.text:
multiple times a day,
and you don't even know it.

77.92.text:
So if you're in the tech industry,
you for sure have heard of Linus Torvalds

85.14.text:
and almost none of you
have ever heard of me.

102.67.text: Wow, this guy is the boss

104.34.text:
of one of the 17 most influential guys
of the century,

107.49.text: wrote the world's most prolific software.

110.17.text:
Who else works for this guy.
The person who created the Internet?

116.02.text:
So first of all,
no, Al Gore does not work for me.

121.66.text:
But let me show you
a couple of others who do.

125.61.text:
These two.
Especially that little girl there.

130.19.text:
That's my daughter.
My 4½-year-old daughter, Nisha.

135.53.text:
And what's funny is Nisha actually shares
a lot in common with Linus Torvalds.

147.83.text: First of all, they're both adorable.

160.91.text:
And finally, neither of them listens
to anything that I say.

170.49.text: In other words, I'm nobody's boss.

174.24.text:
But fortunately, Linus Torvalds
doesn't really need a boss.

177.62.text: He's got this great mascot, this penguin.

180.84.text:
And Linux really has done
very successfully despite me.

187.20.text: And let me show you a few numbers,

189.26.text:
just to give you an idea
of what this looks like.

208.38.text:
700,000 televisions are sold
every single day running Linux.

212.83.text:
92% of the world's high-performance
computing systems

217.07.text:
that predict climate change,
forecast the weather,

219.95.text:
run the CERN supercollider,
are all running Linux.

223.65.text:
85% of the world's
global equity trading platforms run Linux.

230.03.text:
The New York Stock Exchange,
the Tokyo Stock Exchange,

234.74.text: most of our economy runs on Linux.

238.20.text:
1000 trillion dollars
is the amount of transactions

242.71.text:
that happen on just one Linux system,
the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

246.98.text:
It runs Google, Facebook, Amazon,
most of the Internet;

253.16.text:
it is by far the world's
most widely deployed software.

260.14.text:
So, how does Linus do it?
And why should you care, for that matter?

273.11.text: by working with thousands of developers,

276.76.text:
all across the world,
in different countries,

280.98.text: performing a grand act of creation.

285.16.text:
And I'm just a bit player
in this grand play

289.44.text:
that's been unfolding
over the last 20 years.

293.32.text:
But as a witness to all of this,
and technically as Linus's boss,

297.58.text:
I've learned some lessons
that I'd like to share with you today,

302.25.text:
so that you might become
better collaborators,

305.52.text: so that you might achieve the same success

309.83.text:
as someone like Linus
and something like Linux.

315.32.text:
And some of these lessons
may surprise you.

319.14.text:
The first lesson I learned:
don't dream big, don't dream big.

326.72.text:
This is an email from Linus Torvalds
over 20 years ago,

335.02.text:
"I'm not doing anything big,
just something for fun."

341.21.text:
And what's interesting here,
whether it was intentional or not,

344.68.text:
Linus was paraphrasing
a poet, Robert Frost, who said,

349.79.text:
"Don't aim for success,
if that's what you want.

354.29.text:
Do what you love and believe in
and it will follow."

359.60.text:
And I think it's appropriate
that Linus was paraphrasing a poem,

365.38.text:
because what's happening
behind thousands of computer screens

371.20.text: all over the world is a renaissance.

375.65.text:
The Michelangelos and the da Vincis
and the Raphaels of their day

383.51.text: And they're doing it because they love it.

386.40.text:
Linus felt so strongly about this
that he wrote an entire book on it.

391.09.text: And he titled it "Just for Fun."

394.44.text:
Because when you're doing this kind
of grand creation and collaboration,

399.33.text:
when you're doing it because
you love it and you believe in it,

405.61.text:
there is a difference between
a house-painter and da Vinci.

409.43.text:
And the grand code poets
who are writing this

412.83.text: truly believe in what they're doing.

415.03.text:
It is making a huge difference
throughout the world.

420.34.text:
And because they believe in it so much,
they don't care about lesson 2,

425.88.text: which is: give it all away. Give it away.

430.90.text: You see, Linux is open source.

434.07.text:
Anybody can take and use it
completely for free.

438.84.text:
You don't have to ask permission,
you can just take Linux,

442.01.text: grab it, build anything you want.

443.81.text:
In fact the only thing you have to do
is if you make changes to Linux,

447.39.text:
and improve it, you have to share
those changes with everybody else.

452.81.text:
And when I tell people this, they think,
"You guys are idiots."

457.62.text:
You should have seen the crest-fallen
look on my wife's face on our first date

461.67.text: when I told her I worked in a non-profit.

467.02.text:
Nobody can make any money
giving things away, right?

470.98.text:
Well, that's not true,
and I'm going to prove it to you.

474.15.text: What if I showed you 3 companies:

476.85.text:
one based entirely on free
and open-source software,

480.89.text:
one based partially on free
and open-source software,

483.75.text:
and one that's completely based
on closed software,

486.43.text:
they don't give anything away,
they sell it.

488.49.text:
What do you think the results
from those companies would look like?

492.12.text: Well, here's what it would look like.

494.44.text:
This is a chart showing
Red Hat, IBM and Microsoft's results

500.68.text: And at the top, Red Hat,

502.86.text:
a software company
that gives away free software,

507.25.text:
that bases their entire company
on free software self-service and support,

513.24.text:
has gone up almost 200%
in the last 5 years.

518.16.text:
IBM, which all of you have heard of,
it might surprise you to know

522.60.text: they sell billions of dollars of hardware

525.62.text:
which contain
almost entirely free software.

530.69.text:
And Microsoft at the bottom
sells closed software

534.26.text:
that they create by themselves
and sell for a price,

537.82.text:
in the last half-decade they have returned
almost no shareholder value.

544.41.text:
So when I tell people this, they say,
"OK, Jim, that makes sense, we get it,

550.34.text:
but there's just one hole we can put
into your argument.

555.10.text:
I mean it makes sense,
Red Hat's doing well,

558.05.text:
this is a movement
that we think is the future,

564.62.text: You think you all got me, right?

568.09.text: How many people here have an iPhone?

570.86.text:
Alright. I want you
to do something with me.

573.51.text: Take it out, go into the Settings,

576.81.text: go into General, About and Legal Notices.

581.69.text:
And you're going to see
something interesting in there.

584.61.text:
Inside of every iPhone,
every iPad, there is free software.

592.00.text:
You'll see the GNU public license
from the Free Software Foundation,

595.89.text:
you will see the names of prominent
open-source developers,

599.20.text:
you will see oodles and oodles
of free software,

602.82.text:
because Apple knows something
that many people don't,

607.30.text: but that I'm showing you today.

609.43.text:
Which is when you stand
on the shoulders of giants,

612.28.text:
when you use free software
and take part in this grand collaboration,

616.84.text: you can innovate at ever higher levels.

621.15.text:
And that's what Apple does
and it's pretty smart.

624.51.text:
So if anybody tells you
you can't make money

627.02.text:
by giving things away,
you tell them they are wrong.

631.67.text: And then tell them about my next lesson.

636.01.text:
The best way to get something done
is not to have a plan.

645.02.text:
The plan for Linux is there is no plan.
Right?

651.63.text:
but you're not seeing the power
of self-forming communities.

657.58.text:
When you collaborate, you want people
to create things organically.

662.36.text: And that's what happens within Linux.

664.95.text:
Organically, communities come together
to solve their problems

669.04.text:
that if Linus Torvalds or me
or anybody had tried to plan out,

673.04.text: they would never have thought of.

674.69.text:
That's why Linux runs
on a small hand-held phone

678.20.text:
and also powers the world's largest
supercomputers at the same time.

684.75.text:
is an incredible
cross-pollination of ideas,

688.32.text:
where the person trying
to save on battery life in a phone

692.54.text:
by controlling the amount
of power Linux uses

695.09.text:
helps the guy running
the world's biggest computer,

697.49.text:
because the number one cost
is not the hardware,

702.87.text:
it's not the software,
it's the power in cooling.

706.44.text:
So by creating
these self-forming communities,

708.89.text:
they're exchanging these ideas incredibly,
adding all this incredible value

713.05.text:
and producing at a pace
that's unprecedented.

716.50.text:
And let me just show you
how unprecedented that pace is.

724.80.text:
That's the number of lines of code
added to and subtracted from Linux

731.74.text:
A million lines of code were added
to Linux just in the last year.

747.25.text:
Every single hour of every single day,
7 changes happen in Linux.

752.41.text:
It is unprecedented and has resulted in
over 10 billion dollars of value creation

761.03.text:
The most successful
collaborative development project

765.21.text:
407 companies, thousands of individuals
coming together in harmony.

771.65.text:
And speaking of harmony, that leads me
to the next lesson, which is:

776.38.text:
If you're working that fast,
and with that many people

781.28.text:
you'd think you'd have to be
good at collaborating. Right?

785.63.text:
And you'd think you'd have to be
a pretty nice person

788.11.text:
to get along with all of these people
from different backgrounds.

791.15.text:
Well, you would be wrong.
You don't always have to be nice.

794.87.text:
In fact, Linus Torvalds,
sometimes he's not so nice!

804.19.text:
Did I mention he doesn't listen
to anything I have to say?

809.75.text:
But what Linus is doing here,
is he's engaging in a flame war.

813.81.text:
Flame wars are how coders
often communicate.

816.33.text:
They criticize each other,
they defend their ideas,

821.61.text:
In this world, code talks and BS walks.
Right?

826.58.text:
And you'd think this would be
a bad way to create software.

829.32.text:
Yelling at each other all the time,
these guys are pretty mean.

834.00.text:
University of California, Berkeley,
did a study about how ideas are created,

838.50.text: how you can create the best ideas.

840.87.text:
They took a bunch of people
and they put them into groups.

843.49.text:
One group was given
traditional brainstorming instructions.

847.30.text:
No idea's a bad idea,
don't criticize, all of that.

850.99.text:
How many people here have brainstormed?
Right. Of course.

854.00.text: Another group was given the instructions:

860.17.text:
The debate group didn't just do better,
they crushed it.

864.72.text:
They came up with
an order of magnitude better ideas.

870.14.text: And so what does all of this mean?

873.76.text: How can you not dream big, give it away,

878.01.text:
not have have a plan and be a jerk
and get anything done collaboratively?

885.86.text: Maybe Linus Torvalds can get away with it.

890.05.text:
But other people
are catching onto this too.

893.02.text:
And this is really
the future of collaboration.

895.16.text:
And I'm going to show you that
by asking you a a quick question.

898.35.text:
Who do you think said
the following statements?

904.67.text:
The best idea and implementation
should always win.

909.83.text: The hacker way is an approach to building

912.63.text:
that involves continuous improvement
and iteration.

915.71.text:
Hackers believe that
something can always be better

920.01.text: and that nothing is ever complete.

926.28.text:
Sounds like something
Linus Torvalds would say, right?

928.86.text:
In fact, he's said things like this over
and over again over the last 20 years.

939.77.text:
And what's more important than the fact
that Mark Zuckerberg said it,

945.81.text:
Mark Zuckerberg said this
on the eve of Facebook's IPO.

951.47.text:
This guy was about to become
a multi-billionaire.

954.51.text:
And on the eve of the most anticipated
financial event of the last decade, INTAC,

960.89.text:
he didn't talk about price-earnings ratio
or profitability.

964.26.text: Instead he wrote a letter titled:

966.23.text:
"The Hacker Way: Code wins arguments,
may the best idea and implementation win."

973.41.text:
Because Mark Zuckerberg
didn't have to be taught these lessons,

977.71.text:
When he created Facebook,
he grabbed Linux,

979.94.text:
he grabbed free software, and he created
the world's largest social network.

984.63.text:
And he was following
a form of collaboration

987.51.text: that has introduced an entirely new genre

990.37.text:
of the way that people
can get things done.

996.01.text:
And this new genre of collaboration
can be summed up in a simple idea.

1001.27.text: All of us are smarter than any one of us.

1008.63.text:
Because you see,
there's a whole generation

1013.43.text:
of code poets out there,
working furiously.

1018.35.text:
Poets who love what they do,
who may not always get along,

1022.53.text:
but are creating the next Google
and the next Facebook.

1028.23.text:
These individuals have created
the coal and steel of the information age.

1036.44.text:
And instead of that coal and steel
being owned by the Carnegies,

1048.02.text:
The future is a world
in which you can enrich yourself,

1051.47.text: while at the same time enriching others.

1055.38.text: It's going to be a pretty good place.

1060.75.text:
and I have to admit
I may be talking myself out of a job here,
